abstract: Creates a localized string key from the given string interpolation.

codeExamples.code:
let key = LocalizedStringKey("Date is \(company.foundedDate, style: .offset)")
let text = Text(key) // Text contains "Date is +45 years"

overview:
## Discussion

To create a localized string key from a string interpolation, use the `\()` string interpolation syntax. Swift matches the parameter types in the expression to one of the `appendInterpolation` methods in [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/LocalizedStringKey/StringInterpolation]. The interpolated types can include numeric values, Foundation types, and SwiftUI [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/Text] and [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/Image] instances.

The following example uses a string interpolation with two arguments: an unlabeled [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Foundation/Date] and a [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/Text/DateStyle] labeled `style`. The compiler maps these to the method [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/LocalizedStringKey/StringInterpolation/appendInterpolation(_:style:)] as it builds the string that it creates the [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/LocalizedStringKey] with.

You can write this example more concisely, implicitly creating a [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/LocalizedStringKey] as the parameter to the [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/Text] initializer:

# init(stringInterpolation:)

**Initializer**

Creates a localized string key from the given string interpolation.

## Declaration

```swift
init(stringInterpolation: LocalizedStringKey.StringInterpolation)
```

## Parameters

- **stringInterpolation**: The string interpolation to use as the localization key.

## Discussion

To create a localized string key from a string interpolation, use the `\()` string interpolation syntax. Swift matches the parameter types in the expression to one of the `appendInterpolation` methods in [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/LocalizedStringKey/StringInterpolation]. The interpolated types can include numeric values, Foundation types, and SwiftUI [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/Text] and [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/Image] instances.

The following example uses a string interpolation with two arguments: an unlabeled [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Foundation/Date] and a [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/Text/DateStyle] labeled `style`. The compiler maps these to the method [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/LocalizedStringKey/StringInterpolation/appendInterpolation(_:style:)] as it builds the string that it creates the [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/LocalizedStringKey] with.

```swift
let key = LocalizedStringKey("Date is \(company.foundedDate, style: .offset)")
let text = Text(key) // Text contains "Date is +45 years"
```

You can write this example more concisely, implicitly creating a [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/LocalizedStringKey] as the parameter to the [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/Text] initializer:

```swift
let text = Text("Date is \(company.foundedDate, style: .offset)")
```

## Creating a key from an interpolation

- **LocalizedStringKey.StringInterpolation**: Represents the contents of a string literal with interpolations while it’s being built, for use in creating a localized string key.
